awd_titl_txt: Elements: Comprehensive Time Series Data?Analytics for the Prediction of Solar Flares and Eruptions
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar flares are some of the largest explosive events in our solar system. Together with the accompanying eruptions, solar flares have the potential to disrupt the technology we rely on, such as GPS, radars, high-frequency radio communications between aircraft and air traffic control, communication technology that relies on satellites (such as cell phones and Internet), and electricity grid distribution networks. This project aims to, first, improve scientists' understanding of the time-dependent physical and statistical behavior of solar active regions to the point that we can exploit their observations to predict whether and when they will flare, or erupt, in general, and, second, to enable scientists worldwide to perform comparative, reproducible, and data-driven studies on the prediction of solar explosive events. This project, together with its advanced solar flare prediction software infrastructure, will strengthen our nation's efforts to mitigate the potentially catastrophic impact of solar eruptions. Moreover, by helping achieve reliable forecasts of the timing, location, and magnitude of solar flares (already considered as natural disasters), this project will also contribute to mitigating the impact on other types of infrastructure, such as satellites (GPS, Internet, satellite communications), that are critical to not only our national defense but also a broad range of sectors, such as enterprise operations (e.g., oil-drilling) and communications. This award will also invest in the development of a highly educated, diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce trained in an interdisciplinary environment through the educational and research efforts at Georgia State University. 


The goal of this project is to improve the scientists' understanding of eruptive solar events by re-shaping the state-of-the-art on data mining techniques. This project will build cyberinfrastructure for data-driven scientific research on complex multivariate time-series data sets. This includes public releases of comprehensive benchmark data sets ideal for data mining research on multivariate time series classification, regression, and clustering, as well as open-source software for these applications (i.e., the public release of pre-trained models). While the domain area is focused on solar physics, this software and data sets can benefit other domains that involve event tracking and mining of spatiotemporal trajectories (e.g., security and healthcare applications of monitoring movement, traffic and weather data analyses, and business predictions). The project will also advance research in Space Weather forecasting through the delivery of reproducible data-driven solar flare predictions, inspired by new research directions (most notably, time series analysis at an unprecedented level) and spearheaded by the data-driven, physically interpretable machine learning models. In this direction, the projects will produce publicly available flare forecasting big data benchmark data sets aligning with recommendations by the National Science and Technology Council and being useful to both Data Science and Space Weather communities. Finally, this project will advance Computer Science research in data mining and information retrieval areas through the above cutting-edge work on time series data analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION INC

por.por_cntn:
Summary: The project enhanced the understanding of solar active regions and improved predictive capabilities for solar eruptions using big data and machine learning. Spanning from 2019 to 2024, it made significant contributions to heliophysics, computer science, and data science. This initiative involved a collaborative effort among multidisciplinary researchers from Georgia State University (GSU), focusing on leveraging advanced analytics to benefit data-driven space weather predictions.

Key Intellectual Merit Outcomes and Contributions to Advanced Cyberinfrastructure:

  1. SWAN-SF Dataset: A pivotal resource, the Space Weather Analytics for Solar Flares (SWAN-SF) open-access dataset, spanning almost eight years of solar activity, was developed. It compiles 4,098 verified multivariate time series data collections from solar active regions. This dataset integrates over 13,500 flare reports and includes 51 flare-predictive parameters, making it the largest time series dataset for benchmarking machine learning algorithms for solar flare prediction. With over 4,500 downloads since its release, it has become an essential tool for the research community, facilitating further exploration and analysis.
  2. MVTS-Data Toolkit: A fully documented open-source software package for processing multivariate time series data was published. This toolkit supports researchers in analyzing the SWAN-SF dataset, fostering reproducible research and enhancing the broader applied AI community's capabilities. By making this software freely accessible, the project encourages widespread use and adaptation, allowing researchers to enrich their analysis and develop innovative solutions to challenges in machine learning with multivariate time series big data
  3. Extensive Research Dissemination: The project leveraged advanced machine learning techniques to improve solar flare predictions. An interdisciplinary team from GSU developed various methodologies, including outlier detection, data augmentation, and deep learning, to address challenges in training models with extreme class imbalance. These efforts led to improved predictive models now used for operational space weather forecasting. The project produced over 40 peer-reviewed publications, including a dozen journal articles, across fields like heliophysics, computer science, and data science. These works cover data cleaning, multivariate forecasting, and machine learning applications for space weather, promoting collaboration and dialogue within the scientific community.

Key Broader Impacts:

  1. Human Resource Development: The project has positively influenced workforce growth in STEM fields by supporting numerous graduate and undergraduate students. This support has enabled many GSU students to secure positions in academia, including four assistant professors, and various roles in industry, from local companies in Georgia to leaders in the IT sector like Meta. By hiring students from historically underrepresented groups and providing them with research opportunities, the project has made strides in fostering diversity and inclusivity within the scientific community.
  2. Community Engagement and Workshops: The team actively engaged with the data science and heliophysics communities through invited talks, tutorials, and workshops, such as a two-hour tutorial on solar data mining at the IEEE Big Data Conference. This outreach facilitated knowledge transfer and encouraged the adoption of innovative data-driven methodologies in solar research. By sharing insights and promoting dialogue, the project has strengthened connections within the scientific community and inspired further research and collaboration.
  3. Educational Contributions: Faculty members involved in the project integrated their research findings into their curricula, enriching students' educational experiences in related disciplines. This fosters a new generation of scientists equipped to advance big data-driven space weather research. Materials developed have been incorporated into university courses, promoting knowledge and skills in this critical area.
  4. Operational Space Weather Predictions: This research has significantly contributed to improving a near real-time prediction system for solar events at GSU, which reports its predictions to NASA's Community Coordinated Modeling Center for long-term and entirely independent validation. This system enhances the operational capabilities of space weather forecasting, crucial for mitigating the impacts of solar flares on technology and infrastructure on Earth. By providing reliable predictions, the project supports efforts to protect valuable technological assets and ensure the safety and efficiency of various systems affected by space weather.

Conclusion: Overall, the project advanced the scientific understanding of solar flares and improved space weather predictions while establishing advanced cyberinfrastructure resources and novel analytical methodologies that will benefit researchers and practitioners for years. By integrating big data and machine learning, it exemplifies the potential of interdisciplinary research to address complex challenges in space weather forecasting. The integration of advanced data analytics methods not only advances scientific knowledge but also supports practical applications crucial for enhancing the resilience of our modern technology-dependent society against solar disruptions. By enhancing solar flare prediction, training the next generation of scientists, and fostering future research and collaboration, the project has left a lasting impact. Its outcomes influence operational practices and enhance understanding of space weather. This project demonstrates the power of interdisciplinary efforts, paving the way for innovations in space weather forecasting and related fields.


Last Modified: 01/23/2025
Modified by: Rafal A Angryk
